description: Erection of hammer throwing cage, concrete base and apron and surrounding pole mounted floodlights and access ramp
decision_conditions: The development hereby permitted shall begin before the expiration of three years from the date of this permission.Reason: This is required by Section 91 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990.

The facing materials to be used in the construction of the development shall be those specified on the application form and approved drawings or such other materials as have been approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority before the development is commenced and shall thereafter be retained as such. Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The replacement tree planting shown on P102 Proposed Block Plan shall be carried out within the first planting season following completion of the development and the tree planting shall thereafter be maintained for five years to the satisfaction of the Local Planning Authority.  Any trees which die during this period shall be replaced in the first available planting season, and the area shown to be landscaped shall be permanently retained for that purpose only.Reason: In the interests of visual amenity and also that the Local Planning Authority shall be satisfied as to the details of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The development hereby approved shall be implemented in accordance with the mitigation measures recommended in the Atkins Ecological Impact Assessment dated March 2019. Reason: In order to protect the ecology of the area and accord with policies CS3 and DM5 of the Council's adopted LDF Core Strategy April 2012.

The replacement tree planting shown on P102 Proposed Block Plan shall be carried out within the first planting season following completion of the development and the tree planting shall thereafter be maintained for five years to the satisfaction of the Local Planning Authority.  Any trees which die during this period shall be replaced in the first available planting season, and the area shown to be landscaped shall be permanently retained for that purpose only.Reason: In the interests of visual amenity and also that the Local Planning Authority shall be satisfied as to the details of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Notwithstanding the details submitted, a lighting management plan/Scheme ensuring that any lighting is bat and bird friendly shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority before the beneficial use of the facility hereby approved. The development shall only be carried out / used in accordance with the approved details. Reason: In order that the lighting shall not cause nuisance to nearby occupiers or be a source of danger to road users in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.
The proposed changes to the fenestration have been review by the Council's Design Officer and are deemed acceptable.

You have been granted planning permission to build a residential extension.  When undertaking demolition and/or building work, please be considerate to your neighbours and do not undertake work before 8am or after 6pm Monday to Friday, before 8am or after 1pm on a Saturday or at any time on Sundays or Bank Holidays.  Furthermore, please ensure that all vehicles associated with the construction of the development hereby approved are properly washed and cleaned to prevent the passage of mud and dirt onto the adjoining highway. You are advised that the Council does have formal powers to control noise and nuisance under The Control of Pollution Act 1974, the Clean Air Acts and other relevant legislation.  For further information and advice, please contact - Environmental Health Department Pollution Section.

As an application to make a non-material amendment is not an application for planning permission, the existing Town and Country Planning (Development Management Procedure) (England) Order 2015 provisions relating to statutory consultation and publicity do not apply. Notwithstanding the Council has received numerous objections to the application.Section 96A of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (the Act) allows a non-material amendment to be made to an existing planning permission via a simple application procedure with a quick decision time. Section 96A of the Act states that "A local planning authority in England may make a change to any planning permission relating to land in their area if they are satisfied that the change is not material."In deciding whether a change is material, a local planning authority must have regard to the effect of the change, together with any previous changes, on the planning permission as originally granted.The power conferred by Section 96A would allow the Council:(a)	to impose new conditions; (b)	to remove or alter existing conditions.The National Planning Practice Guidance  provides guidance on non-material amendments.The NPPG directs "There is no statutory definition of 'non-material'. This is because it will be dependent on the context of the overall scheme - an amendment that is non-material in one context may be material in another." The focus of the assessment of an application for a non-material amendment is whether the proposed amendment, taken individually or cumulatively with any other previously approved non-material amendment, and in the context or the previously approved development, is non-material or not.Application reference 20/01125/NMA seeks to alter / amend Condition 5 of Planning Permission 20/00378/FUL.Condition 5 of planning permission 20/01125/NMA operates to prevent works which are audible at the site boundary outside of the hours of 08.00 and 18.00 Mondays to Fridays and between 08.00 and 13.00 on Saturdays and not at all on Bank Holidays and Sundays.Application reference 20/01125/NMA seeks to extend the construction hours for a period of 1 calendar month from 08.00 until 21.00 Monday to Saturday. In assessing the application Officers are fully aware of the Written Ministerial Statement (WMS) issued by the Secretary of State at the Ministry of Housing, Communities, and Local Government in relation to extending construction hours. Moreover, Officers are acutely aware of the economic benefits delivered by the construction industry; the benefits of delivering homes quickly, especially at a time when the Council is not able to demonstrate a 5 year supply of housing land; and, by extending hours the ability of the developer to better adhere to Public Health England guidance in terms of social distancing on site. However, an application submitted under Section 96A is not one whereby Officers are able to weigh any merits of the proposal against any demerits, instead it is an assessment of whether the proposed amendment is non-material or not.As identified in the NPPG the assessment of whether a proposed amendment is non-material will in part be dependent on the context of the overall scheme and the location in which the development is situated. Indeed, an amendment that is non-material in one context may be material in another.In the case of the current application, the application site is in a densely populated area, neighbours a number of residential properties, and is in close proximity to a Rehabilitation / Care Home facility, a sensitive use with sensitive users.Taking into account the context of the application site, Officers consider that an amendment to Condition 5, to facilitate longer construction hours, could have an unreasonable impact on the residents of the surrounding roads, in particular the Rehabilitation / Care Home facility. The applicant has submitted a statement on suggested mitigation. The mitigation promoted by the applicant focuses on adherence to the approved Construction Management Plan (CMP). However, no alterations / amendments are proposed to the CMP to accommodate / address working later into the evenings. Taking into account the limited mitigation package proposed by the applicant along with the context of the site, a site in a densely populated area in close proximity to a Rehabilitation / Care Home facility, Officers conclude that the amendment would be greater than non-material and as such conclude that the application should be refused. In arriving at this decision Officers are cognisant of the importance of the construction industry and the vital role it plays in the local / regional economy. Moreover, Officers acknowledge the WMS of the Secretary of State, and agree with him that in the right circumstances, at the right site, an extension to construction hours should be approved. However, for the reasons cited above, in this instance, Officers consider that the application should be refused.This decision should not be interpreted as a position statement on how the WMS will be applied across the Borough. Each application will be dealt with on its own merits.Please note working beyond the construction hours set out in Condition 5 of Planning Permission 20/00378/FUL might constitute a breach of planning control.

The proposed extensions and alterations are considered to fall within the parameters of  permitted development as set out under schedule 2, Part 1, Class B & C of the Town and County Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015

Provide clear photos of each tree, labelled T.1, T.2  (as above) and so on, in order that they can be identified according to the list of works you wish to carry out and the matching numbered plan showing the location of each tree. This will enable the Council to provide you with a timely decision in line with the standard processing times.
Please provide existing roof plans at a recognised scale of 1:50 or 1:100, providing a scale bar, showing the outline of entire property not just part and showing dimensions of proposed work.

Please confirm description of proposed works "Removal of Condition 8 (CO2 Emissions) of Planning Permission 18/12895/FUL (Demolition of existing single storey dwelling and erection of 2x two storey semi detached dwellings with accommodation in the roofspace) to allow no reduction versus Part L of the Building Regulations."
Due to the length of time that has elapsed, please can you submit the existing and proposed plans as an entire set, so that any previous plans can be superceeded.

Please provide existing plans similar to proposed drawing 20/18/12 you have already provided , showing  'Existing'  Street Side Front Elevation and Front Wall Garden Plan at a recognised scale of 1:50 or 1:100, providing a scale bar, indicating all key dimensions.
